articles.headline: Young and Global Need Not Apply in Japan
articles.snippet: Critics say the reluctance of businesses to hire Western-educated graduates who return to the homeland hurts some of Japan’s increasingly globalized industries.
articles.abstract: Critics say the reluctance of businesses to hire Western-educated graduates who return to the homeland hurts some of Japan’s increasingly globalized industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Ronan Sato, a graduate student in applied statistics at Oxford, has always been keen to work in his native Japan. But at a careers fair for overseas Japanese students, he found that corporate Japan did not return his enthusiasm.

articles.headline: Most Aid to Athens Circles Back to Europe
articles.snippet: Much of the money provided by international lenders to the Greek government is flowing directly back to those lenders.
articles.abstract: Much of the money provided by international lenders to the Greek government is flowing directly back to those lenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Its membership in the euro currency union hanging in the balance, Greece continues to receive billions of euros in emergency assistance from a so-called troika of lenders overseeing its bailout.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Even in Coal Country, the Fight for an Industry
articles.snippet: With the coal industry under siege across the country, an announcement that the operator of the Big Sandy power plant near Louisa, Ky., planned to switch to natural gas prompted an uproar.
articles.abstract: With the coal industry under siege across the country, an announcement that the operator of the Big Sandy power plant near Louisa, Ky., planned to switch to natural gas prompted an uproar.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISA, Ky. — For generations, coal has been king in this Appalachian town. It provided heat, light and jobs for the hundreds of people who worked in the nearby coal mines and the smoke-coughing Big Sandy power plant that burned their black bounty.

articles.headline: Tech Suits Endanger Innovation
articles.snippet: Companies are wielding patents as weapons in a blizzard of intellectual property lawsuits, which could have a devastating effect on society as a whole by short-circuiting innovation.
articles.abstract: Companies are wielding patents as weapons in a blizzard of intellectual property lawsuits, which could have a devastating effect on society as a whole by short-circuiting innovation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Casual observers would find little in common between the smartphones in their pockets and the funky backbeat of the Beastie Boys’ Car Thief. But these two creations will go down together in the annals of creativity as reminders of the flaws in our intellectual property laws.

articles.headline: Nomination His, Romney Steps Up Attack on Obama
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney, who formally secured the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday, is unleashing an offensive to further undermine confidence in President Obama.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney, who formally secured the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday, is unleashing an offensive to further undermine confidence in President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney, having initially weathered the first sustained general election attack, is entering a critical 90-day stretch to the Republican convention on relatively equal footing with the White House and is unleashing a new offensive to win over independent voters and further undermine confidence in President Obama’s stewardship of the economy.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Challenges Mount for Chinese Maker of Electric Cars
articles.snippet: Investors and analysts have questioned whether the BYD Company has the technology or the manufacturing quality to be an enduring competitor in the Chinese auto market.
articles.abstract: Investors and analysts have questioned whether the BYD Company has the technology or the manufacturing quality to be an enduring competitor in the Chinese auto market.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Four years ago, the BYD Company promoted the electric battery technology it was developing as a way to help China transform the automobile. No less an investor than Warren E. Buffett, one of the world’s richest men, boasted about the company’s prospects and bought a 10 percent stake.

articles.headline: Wasting Time Is New Divide in Digital Era
articles.snippet: As access to devices has spread, children in poorer families are spending considerably more time using them for purposes other than for education.
articles.abstract: As access to devices has spread, children in poorer families are spending considerably more time using them for purposes other than for education.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the 1990s, the term “digital divide” emerged to describe technology’s haves and have-nots. It inspired many efforts to get the latest computing tools into the hands of all Americans, particularly low-income families.

articles.headline: India’s Economy Slows, With Global Implications
articles.snippet: India’s problems have dampened hopes that it, along with China and other non-Western economies, might help revive global growth.
articles.abstract: India’s problems have dampened hopes that it, along with China and other non-Western economies, might help revive global growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s coalition government just celebrated the third anniversary of its tenure with a self-congratulatory banquet that could not have been more poorly timed: India’s currency, the rupee, is falling; investment is down; inflation is rising; and deficits are eating away at government coffers.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Israeli Official Weighs an Imposed Palestinian Border
articles.snippet: Israel’s defense minister, Ehud Barak, on Wednesday became the most senior member of the government to suggest bypassing a stagnant peace process.
articles.abstract: Israel’s defense minister, Ehud Barak, on Wednesday became the most senior member of the government to suggest bypassing a stagnant peace process.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Defense Minister Ehud Barak said Wednesday that Israel should consider imposing the borders of a future Palestinian state, becoming the most senior government official to suggest bypassing a stagnant peace process.

articles.headline: Ex-Liberian Leader Gets 50 Years for War Crimes
articles.snippet: Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, is the first former head of state convicted by an international tribunal since the Nuremberg trials.
articles.abstract: Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, is the first former head of state convicted by an international tribunal since the Nuremberg trials.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEIDSCHENDAM, the Netherlands — Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia and a once-powerful warlord, was sentenced on Wednesday to 50 years in prison for his role in atrocities committed in Sierra Leone during its civil war in the 1990s.
articles.byline: By Marlise Simons and J. David Goodman
